Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I would like to introduce you
to my favorite parasite. There are millions that I could choose from and this is it: it's called the jewel wasp. You can find it 
in parts of Africa and Asia. It's a little under an inch long, and it is a beautiful looking parasite. Now, you may be saying to yourself, "This is not a parasite. It's not a tapeworm, it's not a virus, how could a wasp be a parasite?" You are probably thinking 
about regular wasps, you know, the ones that build 
paper nests as their house. Well, the thing is that the jewel wasp makes its house inside 
a living cockroach. Here's how it happens. A jewel wasp is flying around, 
looking for a cockroach. When it sees one, it lands 
and bites on its wing. So, I'll be the cockroach. Be-wha! Bewha! And the cockroach starts shaking it off, "Get away from me!" The wasp very quickly starts
stinging the cockroach. All of a sudden, the cockroach can't move, for about a minute. And then it recovers and stands up. It could run away now, but it doesn't. It just doesn't want to. It just stays there. It's become a zombie slave. Again, I'm not making this up. The wasp goes off, it walks away and finds a hole and digs it out, makes it into a burrow. It walks back. This can take up to half an hour. The cockroach is still there. What do we do now? The wasps grabs onto one of the antenna, bites down on it, of the cockroach, and pulls the cockroach. And the cockroach says, "Alright," and walks like a dog on a leash. The wasp takes it 
all the way down into the burrow. The cockroach says, "Nice place." The wasp takes care of some business and then goes and leaves the burrow and seals it shut, leaving the cockroach entombed 
in darkness, still alive. The cockroach says, "Alright, 
I'll stay here if you want." Now, I mentioned that 
the cockroach took care, ah, the wasp took care 
of a little business before it left the burrow. The business was laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach. The egg hatches. Out comes a wasp larva. It looks kind of like 
a maggot with big, nasty jaws. It chews a hole into the cockroach and starts to feed from the outside. It gets bigger, 
like you can see over here. And then when it gets big enough, it decides to crawl into the hole, into the cockroach. So now it's inside 
the still-living cockroach and the cockroach doesn't mind much. This goes on for about a month. The larva grows and grows and grows, then makes a pupa, 
kind of like a cocoon. Inside there it grows eyes, it grows wings, it grows legs, the cockroach is still alive, 
still waiting. Finally the wasp is ready to leave, and that's when the cockroach finally dies because the fullly-formed adult wasp crawls out of the cockroach's dying body. The wasp shakes itself off, climbs out of the burrow, goes and finds another wasp to mate with to start this whole, crazy cycle again. So, this is not science fiction, this happens every day, 
all over the world. And scientists are 
totally fascinated by this. They're just starting to figure out
how all this happens. And, when you really start 
to look at the science of it, you start to kind of respect 
this very creepy wasp. You see, the thing is that 
when it attacks the cockroach, it's not just stinging wildly, it delivers two precise stings. It knows this cockroach's nervous system like you know the back of your hand. The first sting goes to that spot there, called the "walking rhythm generators," and, as you can guess, those are the neurons that send signals to the legs to move. It blocks the channels 
that the neurons use to send these signals. So the cockroach wants to go, 
it wants to run away, but it can't because 
it can't move its legs. And that lasted for about a minute. This is really sophisticated pharmacology. We actually use the same method, a drug called Ivermectin, to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm that gets into your eye. If you take Ivermectin, 
you paralyze the worm using the same strategy. Now, we discovered this in the 1970s, the wasp has been doing this for millions of years. Then comes the second sting. Now the second sting actually hits two places along the way. And to try to imagine how this can happen, I want you to picture yourself with a friend who's got a very long, very, very scary looking needle. And your friend, or at least you thought he was your friend, sticks it in your neck, goes into your skull, stops off at one part of your brain and injects some drugs, then keeps going in your brain and injects some more. These are two particular spots, marked here, "SEG", and you can see the tip of it in the brain, marked "Br". Now, we can do this, but it's really hard for us. It's called stereotactic drug delivery. You have to put a patient in a big metal frame to hold them still, you need CAT Scans to know where you're going, so you look at the picture and say, "Are we going the right way?" The jewel wasp has sensors on its stinger and scientists think that it can actually feel its way through the cockroach's brain until it gets to the exact, right place, and then penetrates an individual neuron and then delivers the goods. So, this is quite amazing stuff, and what seems to happen then is that the wasp is taking away the control that the cockroach has over its own body. It's taking away the cockroach's free will. We didn't really appreciate that cockroaches have free will until this wasp showed us. And, we have no idea how it's doing this, we don't know yet what the venom has in it and we don't know which circuits it's hitting in the cockroach's brain, and I think that's why this is, most of all, my favorite parasite because we have so much left to learn from it. Thank you very much.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the scientific name for the Jewel Wasp?
Options: A. Ampulex compressa, B. Lamprima aurata, C. Rhinotia hemistictus, D. Bombus terrestris
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the parasite introduced by the speaker? Options: A. Tapeworm, B. Jewel wasp, C. Virus, D. Cockroach Correct Option: B
Question 2: Where can the jewel wasp be found? Options: A. Only in Africa, B. Only in Asia, C. Parts of Africa and Asia, D. All over the world Correct Option: C
Question 3: What does the jewel wasp do to the cockroach after stinging it? Options: A. It kills the cockroach, B. It makes the cockroach run away, C. It turns the cockroach into a zombie slave, D. It leaves the cockroach alone Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the wasp laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach? Options: A. To feed the cockroach, B. To protect the cockroach, C. To create a new wasp larva, D. To scare the cockroach Correct Option: C
Question 5: How does the wasp larva feed from the cockroach? Options: A. From the inside of the cockroach's body, B. From the outside of the cockroach's body, C. From the cockroach's antennae, D. From the cockroach's wings Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the purpose of the wasp's second sting? Options: A. To kill the cockroach, B. To make the cockroach run away, C. To take away the cockroach's free will, D. To make the cockroach stronger Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the drug that is used to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm? Options: A. Ivermectin, B. Jewel wasp venom, C. Cockroach venom, D. Tapeworm venom Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does the jewel wasp deliver its venom to the cockroach's brain? Options: A. It uses a long needle, B. It uses a sensor on its stinger to feel its way through the cockroach's brain, C. It uses a CAT Scan to locate the exact spot, D. It uses a big metal frame to hold the cockroach still Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the jewel wasp's ability to take away the cockroach's free will? Options: A. It shows that cockroaches are not intelligent, B. It shows that cockroaches have free will, C. It shows that the jewel wasp is a highly sophisticated parasite, D. It shows that the cockroach is a zombie Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is the jewel wasp considered the speaker's favorite parasite? Options: A. Because it is the most intelligent parasite, B. Because it is the most beautiful parasite, C. Because it is still a mystery and has much to be learned from it, D. Because it is the most deadly parasite Correct Option: C

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I would like to introduce you
to my favorite parasite. There are millions that I could choose from and this is it: it's called the jewel wasp. You can find it 
in parts of Africa and Asia. It's a little under an inch long, and it is a beautiful looking parasite. Now, you may be saying to yourself, "This is not a parasite. It's not a tapeworm, it's not a virus, how could a wasp be a parasite?" You are probably thinking 
about regular wasps, you know, the ones that build 
paper nests as their house. Well, the thing is that the jewel wasp makes its house inside 
a living cockroach. Here's how it happens. A jewel wasp is flying around, 
looking for a cockroach. When it sees one, it lands 
and bites on its wing. So, I'll be the cockroach. Be-wha! Bewha! And the cockroach starts shaking it off, "Get away from me!" The wasp very quickly starts
stinging the cockroach. All of a sudden, the cockroach can't move, for about a minute. And then it recovers and stands up. It could run away now, but it doesn't. It just doesn't want to. It just stays there. It's become a zombie slave. Again, I'm not making this up. The wasp goes off, it walks away and finds a hole and digs it out, makes it into a burrow. It walks back. This can take up to half an hour. The cockroach is still there. What do we do now? The wasps grabs onto one of the antenna, bites down on it, of the cockroach, and pulls the cockroach. And the cockroach says, "Alright," and walks like a dog on a leash. The wasp takes it 
all the way down into the burrow. The cockroach says, "Nice place." The wasp takes care of some business and then goes and leaves the burrow and seals it shut, leaving the cockroach entombed 
in darkness, still alive. The cockroach says, "Alright, 
I'll stay here if you want." Now, I mentioned that 
the cockroach took care, ah, the wasp took care 
of a little business before it left the burrow. The business was laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach. The egg hatches. Out comes a wasp larva. It looks kind of like 
a maggot with big, nasty jaws. It chews a hole into the cockroach and starts to feed from the outside. It gets bigger, 
like you can see over here. And then when it gets big enough, it decides to crawl into the hole, into the cockroach. So now it's inside 
the still-living cockroach and the cockroach doesn't mind much. This goes on for about a month. The larva grows and grows and grows, then makes a pupa, 
kind of like a cocoon. Inside there it grows eyes, it grows wings, it grows legs, the cockroach is still alive, 
still waiting. Finally the wasp is ready to leave, and that's when the cockroach finally dies because the fullly-formed adult wasp crawls out of the cockroach's dying body. The wasp shakes itself off, climbs out of the burrow, goes and finds another wasp to mate with to start this whole, crazy cycle again. So, this is not science fiction, this happens every day, 
all over the world. And scientists are 
totally fascinated by this. They're just starting to figure out
how all this happens. And, when you really start 
to look at the science of it, you start to kind of respect 
this very creepy wasp. You see, the thing is that 
when it attacks the cockroach, it's not just stinging wildly, it delivers two precise stings. It knows this cockroach's nervous system like you know the back of your hand. The first sting goes to that spot there, called the "walking rhythm generators," and, as you can guess, those are the neurons that send signals to the legs to move. It blocks the channels 
that the neurons use to send these signals. So the cockroach wants to go, 
it wants to run away, but it can't because 
it can't move its legs. And that lasted for about a minute. This is really sophisticated pharmacology. We actually use the same method, a drug called Ivermectin, to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm that gets into your eye. If you take Ivermectin, 
you paralyze the worm using the same strategy. Now, we discovered this in the 1970s, the wasp has been doing this for millions of years. Then comes the second sting. Now the second sting actually hits two places along the way. And to try to imagine how this can happen, I want you to picture yourself with a friend who's got a very long, very, very scary looking needle. And your friend, or at least you thought he was your friend, sticks it in your neck, goes into your skull, stops off at one part of your brain and injects some drugs, then keeps going in your brain and injects some more. These are two particular spots, marked here, "SEG", and you can see the tip of it in the brain, marked "Br". Now, we can do this, but it's really hard for us. It's called stereotactic drug delivery. You have to put a patient in a big metal frame to hold them still, you need CAT Scans to know where you're going, so you look at the picture and say, "Are we going the right way?" The jewel wasp has sensors on its stinger and scientists think that it can actually feel its way through the cockroach's brain until it gets to the exact, right place, and then penetrates an individual neuron and then delivers the goods. So, this is quite amazing stuff, and what seems to happen then is that the wasp is taking away the control that the cockroach has over its own body. It's taking away the cockroach's free will. We didn't really appreciate that cockroaches have free will until this wasp showed us. And, we have no idea how it's doing this, we don't know yet what the venom has in it and we don't know which circuits it's hitting in the cockroach's brain, and I think that's why this is, most of all, my favorite parasite because we have so much left to learn from it. Thank you very much.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following best defines a parasite?
Options: A. A close, prolonged association between two or more different organisms of different species that may, but does not necessarily, benefit each member, B. An organism that lives in a close relationship with another organism, its host, and causes it harm, C. An anatomical structure that is capable of being introverted and exclusively focuses upon itself, D. A plant considered undesirable, unattractive, or troublesome, especially one growing where it is not wanted, as in a garden
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the parasite introduced by the speaker? Options: A. Tapeworm, B. Jewel wasp, C. Virus, D. Cockroach Correct Option: B
Question 2: Where can the jewel wasp be found? Options: A. Only in Africa, B. Only in Asia, C. Parts of Africa and Asia, D. All over the world Correct Option: C
Question 3: What does the jewel wasp do to the cockroach after stinging it? Options: A. It kills the cockroach, B. It makes the cockroach run away, C. It turns the cockroach into a zombie slave, D. It leaves the cockroach alone Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the wasp laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach? Options: A. To feed the cockroach, B. To protect the cockroach, C. To create a new wasp larva, D. To scare the cockroach Correct Option: C
Question 5: How does the wasp larva feed from the cockroach? Options: A. From the inside of the cockroach's body, B. From the outside of the cockroach's body, C. From the cockroach's antennae, D. From the cockroach's wings Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the purpose of the wasp's second sting? Options: A. To kill the cockroach, B. To make the cockroach run away, C. To take away the cockroach's free will, D. To make the cockroach stronger Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the drug that is used to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm? Options: A. Ivermectin, B. Jewel wasp venom, C. Cockroach venom, D. Tapeworm venom Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does the jewel wasp deliver its venom to the cockroach's brain? Options: A. It uses a long needle, B. It uses a sensor on its stinger to feel its way through the cockroach's brain, C. It uses a CAT Scan to locate the exact spot, D. It uses a big metal frame to hold the cockroach still Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the jewel wasp's ability to take away the cockroach's free will? Options: A. It shows that cockroaches are not intelligent, B. It shows that cockroaches have free will, C. It shows that the jewel wasp is a highly sophisticated parasite, D. It shows that the cockroach is a zombie Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is the jewel wasp considered the speaker's favorite parasite? Options: A. Because it is the most intelligent parasite, B. Because it is the most beautiful parasite, C. Because it is still a mystery and has much to be learned from it, D. Because it is the most deadly parasite Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I would like to introduce you
to my favorite parasite. There are millions that I could choose from and this is it: it's called the jewel wasp. You can find it 
in parts of Africa and Asia. It's a little under an inch long, and it is a beautiful looking parasite. Now, you may be saying to yourself, "This is not a parasite. It's not a tapeworm, it's not a virus, how could a wasp be a parasite?" You are probably thinking 
about regular wasps, you know, the ones that build 
paper nests as their house. Well, the thing is that the jewel wasp makes its house inside 
a living cockroach. Here's how it happens. A jewel wasp is flying around, 
looking for a cockroach. When it sees one, it lands 
and bites on its wing. So, I'll be the cockroach. Be-wha! Bewha! And the cockroach starts shaking it off, "Get away from me!" The wasp very quickly starts
stinging the cockroach. All of a sudden, the cockroach can't move, for about a minute. And then it recovers and stands up. It could run away now, but it doesn't. It just doesn't want to. It just stays there. It's become a zombie slave. Again, I'm not making this up. The wasp goes off, it walks away and finds a hole and digs it out, makes it into a burrow. It walks back. This can take up to half an hour. The cockroach is still there. What do we do now? The wasps grabs onto one of the antenna, bites down on it, of the cockroach, and pulls the cockroach. And, we have no idea how it's doing this, we don't know yet what the venom has in it and we don't know which circuits it's hitting in the cockroach's brain, and I think that's why this is, most of all, my favorite parasite because we have so much left to learn from it. Thank you very much.

Options: A. Fragmented interspacial relief, B. Brain medicine delivery (BMD), C. Intraspinal tactical precicion, D. Stereotactic drug delivery
Correct Option: D

The cockroach follows the wasp without any persuasion from the wasp, D. The cockroach never follows the wasp -- the wasp simply lays its eggs while the cockroach is doing its own thing

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I would like to introduce you
to my favorite parasite. There are millions that I could choose from and this is it: it's called the jewel wasp. You can find it 
in parts of Africa and Asia. It's a little under an inch long, and it is a beautiful looking parasite. Now, you may be saying to yourself, "This is not a parasite. It's not a tapeworm, it's not a virus, how could a wasp be a parasite?" You are probably thinking 
about regular wasps, you know, the ones that build 
paper nests as their house. Well, the thing is that the jewel wasp makes its house inside 
a living cockroach. Here's how it happens. A jewel wasp is flying around, 
looking for a cockroach. When it sees one, it lands 
and bites on its wing. So, I'll be the cockroach. Be-wha! Bewha! And the cockroach starts shaking it off, "Get away from me!" The wasp very quickly starts
stinging the cockroach. All of a sudden, the cockroach can't move, for about a minute. And then it recovers and stands up. It could run away now, but it doesn't. It just doesn't want to. It just stays there. It's become a zombie slave. Again, I'm not making this up. The wasp goes off, it walks away and finds a hole and digs it out, makes it into a burrow. It walks back. This can take up to half an hour. The cockroach is still there. What do we do now? The wasps grabs onto one of the antenna, bites down on it, of the cockroach, and pulls the cockroach. And the cockroach says, "Alright," and walks like a dog on a leash. The wasp takes it 
all the way down into the burrow. The cockroach says, "Nice place." The wasp takes care of some business and then goes and leaves the burrow and seals it shut, leaving the cockroach entombed 
in darkness, still alive. The cockroach says, "Alright, 
I'll stay here if you want." Now, I mentioned that 
the cockroach took care, ah, the wasp took care 
of a little business before it left the burrow. The business was laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach. The egg hatches. Out comes a wasp larva. It looks kind of like 
a maggot with big, nasty jaws. It chews a hole into the cockroach and starts to feed from the outside. It gets bigger, 
like you can see over here. And then when it gets big enough, it decides to crawl into the hole, into the cockroach. So now it's inside 
the still-living cockroach and the cockroach doesn't mind much. This goes on for about a month. The larva grows and grows and grows, then makes a pupa, 
kind of like a cocoon. Inside there it grows eyes, it grows wings, it grows legs, the cockroach is still alive, 
still waiting. Finally the wasp is ready to leave, and that's when the cockroach finally dies because the fullly-formed adult wasp crawls out of the cockroach's dying body. The wasp shakes itself off, climbs out of the burrow, goes and finds another wasp to mate with to start this whole, crazy cycle again. So, this is not science fiction, this happens every day, 
all over the world. And scientists are 
totally fascinated by this. They're just starting to figure out
how all this happens. And, when you really start 
to look at the science of it, you start to kind of respect 
this very creepy wasp. You see, the thing is that 
when it attacks the cockroach, it's not just stinging wildly, it delivers two precise stings. It knows this cockroach's nervous system like you know the back of your hand. The first sting goes to that spot there, called the "walking rhythm generators," and, as you can guess, those are the neurons that send signals to the legs to move. It blocks the channels 
that the neurons use to send these signals. So the cockroach wants to go, 
it wants to run away, but it can't because 
it can't move its legs. And that lasted for about a minute. This is really sophisticated pharmacology. We actually use the same method, a drug called Ivermectin, to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm that gets into your eye. If you take Ivermectin, 
you paralyze the worm using the same strategy. Now, we discovered this in the 1970s, the wasp has been doing this for millions of years. Then comes the second sting. Now the second sting actually hits two places along the way. And to try to imagine how this can happen, I want you to picture yourself with a friend who's got a very long, very, very scary looking needle. And your friend, or at least you thought he was your friend, sticks it in your neck, goes into your skull, stops off at one part of your brain and injects some drugs, then keeps going in your brain and injects some more. These are two particular spots, marked here, "SEG", and you can see the tip of it in the brain, marked "Br". Now, we can do this, but it's really hard for us. It's called stereotactic drug delivery. You have to put a patient in a big metal frame to hold them still, you need CAT Scans to know where you're going, so you look at the picture and say, "Are we going the right way?" The jewel wasp has sensors on its stinger and scientists think that it can actually feel its way through the cockroach's brain until it gets to the exact, right place, and then penetrates an individual neuron and then delivers the goods. So, this is quite amazing stuff, and what seems to happen then is that the wasp is taking away the control that the cockroach has over its own body. It's taking away the cockroach's free will. We didn't really appreciate that cockroaches have free will until this wasp showed us. And, we have no idea how it's doing this, we don't know yet what the venom has in it and we don't know which circuits it's hitting in the cockroach's brain, and I think that's why this is, most of all, my favorite parasite because we have so much left to learn from it. Thank you very much.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What moves into the cockroach?
Options: A. Nothing moves into the cockroach -- the wasp larva moves out of the cockroach once it's big / strong enough, B. The adult wasp moves inside in oder to eat the wasp as a final boost of nutrition before mating, C. The wasp larva feeds from the outside until it's big / strong enough to move inside, D. Nothing moves into the cockroach -- the wasp lays the egg inside the cockroach
Correct Option: C

Question 3: What does the jewel wasp do to the cockroach after stinging it? Options: A. It kills the cockroach, B. It makes the cockroach run away, C. It turns the cockroach into a zombie slave, D. It leaves the cockroach alone Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the wasp laying an egg on the underside of the cockroach? Options: A. To feed the cockroach, B. To protect the cockroach, C. To create a new wasp larva, D. To scare the cockroach Correct Option: C
Question 5: How does the wasp larva feed from the cockroach? Options: A. From the inside of the cockroach's body, B. From the outside of the cockroach's body, C. From the cockroach's antennae, D. From the cockroach's wings Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the purpose of the wasp's second sting? Options: A. To kill the cockroach, B. To make the cockroach run away, C. To take away the cockroach's free will, D. To make the cockroach stronger Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the drug that is used to cure river blindness, which is caused by a parasitic worm? Options: A. Ivermectin, B. Jewel wasp venom, C. Cockroach venom, D. Tapeworm venom Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does the jewel wasp deliver its venom to the cockroach's brain? Options: A. It uses a long needle, B. It uses a sensor on its stinger to feel its way through the cockroach's brain, C. It uses a CAT Scan to locate the exact spot, D. It uses a big metal frame to hold the cockroach still Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the jewel wasp's ability to take away the cockroach's free will? Options: A. It shows that cockroaches are not intelligent, B. It shows that cockroaches have free will, C. It shows that the jewel wasp is a highly sophisticated parasite, D. It shows that the cockroach is a zombie Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is the jewel wasp considered the speaker's favorite parasite? Options: A. Because it is the most intelligent parasite, B. Because it is the most beautiful parasite, C. Because it is still a mystery and has much to be learned from it, D. Because it is the most deadly parasite Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
unless we do something to prevent it over the next 40 years we're facing an epidemic of neurologic diseases on a global scale a cheery thought-- on this map every country that's colored blue has more than 20% of its population over the age of 65 this is the world we live in and this is the world your children will live in for 12,000 years the distribution of ages in the human population has looked like a pyramid with the oldest on top it's already flattening out by 2050 it's going to be a column and we'll start to invert this is why it's happening the average lifespan is more than doubled since 1840 and it's increasing currently at the rate of about 5 hours every day and this is why that's not entirely a good thing because over the age of 65 your risk of getting Alzheimer's or Parkinson's disease will increase exponentially by 2050 there'll be about 32 million people in the United States over the age of 80 and unless we do something about it half of them will have Alzheimer's disease and 3 million more will have Parkinson's disease right now those and other neurologic diseases for which we have no cure or prevention cost about a third of a trillion dollars a year it'll be well over a trillion dollars by 2050 Alzheimer's disease starts when a protein that should be folded up properly mis folds into a kind of demented origami so one approach we're taking is to try to design drugs that function like molecular scotch tape to hold the protein into its proper shape that would keep it from forming the tangles that seem to kill large sections of the brain when they do interestingly enough other neurologic diseases which affect very different parts of the brain also show tangles of MIS folded protein which suggests that the approach might be a general one and might be used to cure many neurologic diseases not just Alzheimer's disease there's also a fascinating connection to cancer here because people with neurologic diseases have a very low in cents of most cancers and this is a connection that most people aren't pursuing right now but which were fascinated by most of the important that all of the creative work in this area is being funded by private philanthropies and there's tremendous scope for additional private help here because the government has dropped the ball on much of this I'm afraid in the meantime while we're waiting for all these things to happen here's what you can do for yourself if you want to lower your risk of Parkinson's disease caffeine is protective to some extent nobody knows why head injuries are bad for you they lead to Parkinson's disease and the avian flu is also not a good idea as far as protecting yourself against Alzheimer's disease well it turns out that fish oil has the effect of reducing your risk for Alzheimer's disease you should also keep your blood pressure down because chronic high blood pressure is the biggest single risk factor for Alzheimer's disease it's also the biggest risk factor for glaucoma which is just Alzheimer's disease of the eye and of course when it comes to cognitive effects use it or lose it applies so you want to stay mentally stimulated but hey you're listening to me so you've got that covered and one final thing which people like me luck okay because the clock is ticking for all of us thank

unless we do something to prevent it over the next 40 years we're facing an epidemic of neurologic diseases on a global scale a cheery thought-- on this map every country that's colored blue has more than 20% of its population over the age of 65 this is the world we live in and this is the world your children will live in for 12,000 years the distribution of ages in the human population has looked like a pyramid with the oldest on top it's already flattening out by 2050 it's going to be a column and we'll start to invert this is why it's happening the average lifespan is more than doubled since 1840 and it's increasing currently at the rate of about 5 hours every day and this is why that's not entirely a good thing because over the age of 65 your risk of getting Alzheimer's or Parkinson's disease will increase exponentially by 2050 there'll be about 32 million people in the United States over the age of 80 and unless we do something about it half of them will have Alzheimer's disease and 3 million more will have Parkinson's disease right now those and other neurologic diseases for which we have no cure or prevention cost about a third of a trillion dollars a year it'll be well over a trillion dollars by 2050 Alzheimer's disease starts when a protein that should be folded up properly mis folds into a kind of demented origami so one approach we're taking is to try to design drugs that function like molecular scotch tape to hold the protein into its proper shape that would keep it from forming the tangles that seem to kill large sections of the brain when they do interestingly enough other neurologic diseases which affect very different parts of the brain also show tangles of MIS folded protein which suggests that the approach might be a general one and might be used to cure many neurologic diseases not just Alzheimer's disease there's also a fascinating connection to cancer here because people with neurologic diseases have a very low in cents of most cancers and this is a connection that most people aren't pursuing right now but which were fascinated by most of the important that all of the creative work in this area is being funded by private philanthropies and there's tremendous scope for additional private help here because the government has dropped the ball on much of this I'm afraid in the meantime while we're waiting for all these things to happen here's what you can do for yourself if you want to lower your risk of Parkinson's disease caffeine is protective to some extent nobody knows why head injuries are bad for you they lead to Parkinson's disease and the avian flu is also not a good idea as far as protecting yourself against Alzheimer's disease well it turns out that fish oil has the effect of reducing your risk for Alzheimer's disease you should also keep your blood pressure down because chronic high blood pressure is the biggest single risk factor for Alzheimer's disease it's also the biggest risk factor for glaucoma which is just Alzheimer's disease of the eye and of course when it comes to cognitive effects use it or lose it applies so you want to stay mentally stimulated but hey you're listening to me so you've got that covered and one final thing which people like me luck okay because the clock is ticking for all of us thank

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does Alzheimer's disease start?
Options: A. When a protein that should be folded up properly misfolds, B. When someone endures a head injury, C. When a molecular cell triples in size, D. When someone has a stroke
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the predicted outcome for the distribution of ages in the world's population by 2050, according to the speaker? Options: A. The distribution will remain a pyramid with the oldest on top., B. The distribution will remain the same as it is today., C. The distribution will be a column and will invert by 2050., D. The distribution will decrease due to a decrease in lifespan. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the current rate of increase in the average lifespan, according to the speaker? Options: A. 5 years every decade, B. 5 years every century, C. 5 hours every day, D. 5 years every 10 years Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the speaker, what is the predicted number of people in the United States over the age of 80 by 2050? Options: A. 10 million, B. 20 million, C. 32 million, D. 40 million Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the predicted number of people in the United States with Alzheimer's disease by 2050, according to the speaker? Options: A. 1 million, B. 10 million, C. 15 million, D. Half of the people over the age of 80 (which is 16 million) Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is one approach being taken to design drugs for Alzheimer's disease, according to the speaker? Options: A. To try to design drugs that function like molecular scotch tape to hold the protein into its proper shape., B. To try to design drugs that function like a hammer to break the protein into smaller pieces., C. To try to design drugs that function like a magnet to attract the protein away from the brain., D. To try to design drugs that function like a vacuum to suck the protein out of the brain. Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the speaker, what is a connection between neurologic diseases and cancer? Options: A. People with neurologic diseases have a higher risk of most cancers., B. People with neurologic diseases have a lower risk of most cancers., C. People with neurologic diseases have the same risk of most cancers as people without neurologic diseases., D. There is no connection between neurologic diseases and cancer. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one way to lower your risk of Parkinson's disease, according to the speaker? Options: A. To avoid head injuries., B. To take a lot of caffeine, C. To take a lot of fish oil, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is one way to lower your risk of Alzheimer's disease, according to the speaker? Options: A. To take a lot of fish oil, B. To keep your blood pressure down, C. To stay mentally stimulated, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the speaker, what is the biggest single risk factor for Alzheimer's disease? Options: A. Chronic high blood pressure, B. Head injuries, C. Caffeine intake, D. Fish oil consumption Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the speaker's attitude towards the government's role in funding research on neurologic diseases? Options: A. The speaker thinks the government is doing a great job in funding research on neurologic diseases., B. The speaker thinks the government is doing a good job in funding research on neurologic diseases, but there is still room for improvement., C. The speaker thinks the government has dropped the ball on funding research on neurologic diseases., D. The speaker thinks the government has no role in funding research on neurologic diseases. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content, as both questions discuss the mechanism of Alzheimer's disease and how it can be addressed. The ground truth MCQ asks how Alzheimer's disease starts, and the correct answer is that it starts when a protein misfolds. Question 5 asks about one approach being taken to design drugs for Alzheimer's disease, and the correct answer is to try to design drugs that function like molecular scotch tape to hold the protein into its proper shape, which is directly related to the misfolding of proteins mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. 

While the questions are not identical, Question 5 is the closest match among the generated MCQs in terms of addressing the underlying mechanism of Alzheimer's disease and the approach to addressing it.

**Transcript**:
great creativity in times of need we need great creativity discuss great creativity is astonishingly absurdly rationally irrationally powerful great creativity can spread Toler Champion Freedom make education seem like a bright idea great creativity can turn a spotlight on deprivation or show that deprivation ain't necessarily so great creativity can make politicians electable or parties unelectable it can make war seem like tragedy or fast creativity is the meme maker that puts slogans on our t-shirts and phrases on our lips it's the Pathfinder that shows us a simple Road through an impenetrable moral maze science is clever but great creativity is something less knowable more magical and now we need that magic this is a time of need our climate is changing quickly too quickly and great creativity is needed to do what it does so well to provoke us to think differently with dramatic creative statements to tempt us to act differently with delightful creative scraps here is one such scrap from an initiative I'm involved in using creativity to inspire people to be greener you know rather than drive today I'm going to walk and so he walked and as he walked he saw things strange and wonderful things he would not otherwise have seen a deer with an itchy leg a flying motorcycle a father and daughter separated from a bicycle by a mysterious wall and then he stopped walking in front of him was her the woman who has a child had skipped with him through fields and broken his heart sure she had aged a little in fact she'd aged a lot but he felt all his old passion for her return Ford he called softly that was her name don't say another word Gusty she said for that was his name I know a tent next to a caravan exactly 300 yd from here let's go there and make love in a tent Ford undressed she spread one leg and then the other Gusty Ed her boldly and made love to her rhythmically while she filmed him because she was a keen amateur pornographer the Earth moved for both of them and they live together happily ever after and all because he decided to walk that day we've got the science we've had the debate the moral imperative is on the table great creativity is needed to take it all make it simple and sharp to make it connect to make it make people want to act so this is a call a plea to the incredibly talented uh Ted Community let's get creative against climate change and let's do it soon thank you what does a machine know about itself can it know when it needs to be repaired and when it doesn't in Industries like manufacturing and energy they're using Predictive Analytics to detect signs of trouble helping some companies save Millions on maintenance because Machin seek help before they're broken and don't when they're not that's what I'm working on I'm an IBM let's build a smarter planet

great creativity in times of need we need great creativity discuss great creativity is astonishingly absurdly rationally irrationally powerful great creativity can spread Toler Champion Freedom make education seem like a bright idea great creativity can turn a spotlight on deprivation or show that deprivation ain't necessarily so great creativity can make politicians electable or parties unelectable it can make war seem like tragedy or fast creativity is the meme maker that puts slogans on our t-shirts and phrases on our lips it's the Pathfinder that shows us a simple Road through an impenetrable moral maze science is clever but great creativity is something less knowable more magical and now we need that magic this is a time of need our climate is changing quickly too quickly and great creativity is needed to do what it does so well to provoke us to think differently with dramatic creative statements to tempt us to act differently with delightful creative scraps here is one such scrap from an initiative I'm involved in using creativity to inspire people to be greener you know rather than drive today I'm going to walk and so he walked and as he walked he saw things strange and wonderful things he would not otherwise have seen a deer with an itchy leg a flying motorcycle a father and daughter separated from a bicycle by a mysterious wall and then he stopped walking in front of him was her the woman who has a child had skipped with him through fields and broken his heart sure she had aged a little in fact she'd aged a lot but he felt all his old passion in a tent Ford undressed she spread one leg and then the other Gusty Ed her boldly and made love to her rhythmically while she filmed him because she was a keen amateur pornographer the Earth moved for both of them and they live together happily ever after and all because he decided to walk that day we've got the science we've had the debate the moral imperative is on the table great creativity is needed to take it all make it simple and sharp to make it connect to make it make people want to act so this is a call a plea to the incredibly talented uh Ted Community let's get creative against climate change and let's do it soon thank you what does a machine know about itself can it know when it needs to be repaired and when it doesn't in Industries like manufacturing and energy they're using Predictive Analytics to detect signs of trouble helping some companies save Millions on maintenance because Machin seek help before they're broken and don't when they're not that's what I'm working on I'm an IBM let's build a smarter planet

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I got in my first car accident when I was sixteen. I had just gotten my license and I was driving home when a car pulled into the intersection and bang! It hit me. It had happened that quick. Bang! But when I play that memory back, it doesn't take two seconds. I see the tires of the car rolling through the stop sign, I have time to think, "You know, I think that car is going to hit me." I see the right-hand corner of the hood crumple up like tin foil, I see the red paint flake off and drift off into the air, I can see all of that, like it's happening in slow motion. In my memory, that experience takes ten seconds. But why? Why did that memory play back longer than the actual time it took? This is an interesting phenomenon and it's not just for car accidents, a roller coaster, or a first kiss. These events seem to take longer than they actually take. But why? And when it comes to writing about that experience, how do I get that peculiar feeling across? How do I slow down time as a writer? To get the answer, we have to visit Hollywood. You see, the way filmmakers create slow motion will tell us a lot about how writers can create slow motion. First, let's remember how film works. When the camera turns on, it's not recording motion, it's taking lots and lots of individual pictures. Then when those pictures are played back in the projector, they blend together and create the appearance of motion, like a flip book. So, let's imagine that a camera man needs to film his actress skipping through a field of daisies in regular motion. Ready, action. She skips across the field, he records it, and...cut. Let's say for the sake of easy math that our camera man took 50 pictures, 50 little frames on that length of film. Now, let's take that film and play it back at the rate of 50 frames per 5 seconds. This rate is constant, the projector will always go at the same speed. It's easy, we got 50 frames, so our film takes 5 seconds. She skips across the field... ...and cut! So, then, how do we slow down time in film? How do we create slow motion? Maybe this is a surprise, but we don't take less pictures, we take more pictures. Ready, action! She skips across the field, he records it, and cut. Now we have a lot of film, a long length, let's say 100 frames long. Now, when we play it back, it takes a longer time to get through, and there's the actress in slow motion. Skipping through the field of daisies! Which brings us now to writing. When you're writing a narrative, you may want to use slow motion in one of your scenes. It's a cool effect, just like it is in Hollywood, and it draws the reader's attention to important moments. Well, here's how you do it. You see, when we read, our brain makes the words into pictures and the pictures blend into action. So what we read is what we see in the time it takes us to read it. For example, imagine you're writing a narrative about your game-winning free throw in the championship game. Here's a moment as a writer that you might want to slow down time to really capture the second-by-second tension produced by the scene. You concentrate, you put the pencil to paper, you really want to slow down time, you write, "I shot the ball in the hoop. Time slowed down. Then we won." To read that, takes two seconds; therefore, your reader imagines a scene that takes two seconds. Ball goes up, comes down, done. See, even though you wrote, "time slowed down," you didn't achieve that effect for your reader. Just saying it doesn't make it happen. Now, let's take what we make about film, time slows down with more pictures, and try again. This time write A LOT more. "I bent my knees and held the ball loosely. Letting the ball bounce on the floor once more, I gathered my thoughts. This was the moment. My right arm extended as I released the ball with a gentle flick, it rotated slightly as it arched toward the rim. I held my breath. The ball nudged the back rim, falling through the net with a gentle, satisfying swish. And the crowd exploded from their seats." See, we just slowed down time through our writing. The bottom line is this: there are moments in life that take longer than they actually take. When you're planning out your narrative, think about those moments, those snippets of life that took longer than the watch: the moment of hearing bad news, the moment of hearing good news, the moment of exhilaration when you realize you hit the jump, or the moment when you realize you aren't going to land it. Once you identify these moments in your narrative, you can use this effect of slow motion when you write. Just remember, it's not enough to say, "time slowed down" and it's not enough to throw a couple adjectives in a sentence and call it done either. Descriptive writing is good writing, that's true. But if you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually take up more physical space on the page, use more film so to speak. In doing so, you will create tension and keep your reader interested. And that way, the next time you write, you'll control the camera of your own writing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Using a car accident as an example, what phenomenon does Sitze refer to?
Options: A. Our memories slow down time when exciting things happen, B. Trauma always provides out of body experiences for those involved, C. Insurance premiums don't always increase, especially if an accident happens in areas of expected collision, D. The body responds with certain proactive defense mechanisms during trauma (like raising the hair on your arms)
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the phenomenon described by the author as happening when they recall a car accident from their past? Options: A. The accident took longer than it actually did, B. The author's memory of the accident is more vivid than the actual event, C. The author's memory of the accident is less vivid than the actual event, D. The author's memory of the accident is the same as the actual event Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main idea that the author wants to convey to the reader about writing a narrative? Options: A. The importance of using descriptive language, B. The need to slow down time in writing to capture important moments, C. The role of the author's perspective in shaping the narrative, D. The use of adjectives to create a vivid picture Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the author, how does a filmmaker create slow motion in film? Options: A. By taking fewer pictures, B. By taking more pictures, C. By using a faster film speed, D. By using a slower film speed Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the effect that the author wants to achieve when writing a narrative about a moment that took longer than it actually did? Options: A. To create a sense of urgency, B. To create a sense of tension, C. To create a sense of slow motion, D. To create a sense of relief Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the key to creating slow motion in writing, according to the author? Options: A. Using more adjectives, B. Using more descriptive language, C. Taking up more physical space on the page, D. Using a faster pace Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the author's advice to the reader about how to write a narrative that captures the feeling of slow motion? Options: A. To say "time slowed down" and add a few adjectives, B. To write a lot more and use descriptive language, C. To use a faster pace and more adjectives, D. To use a slower pace and fewer adjectives Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main idea that the author wants to convey to the reader about the role of the author's perspective in shaping the narrative? Options: A. The author's perspective is the only way to tell a story, B. The author's perspective is important, but not the only way to tell a story, C. The author's perspective is not important in shaping the narrative, D. The author's perspective is not relevant to the narrative Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the author's advice to the reader about how to identify moments in life that took longer than they actually did? Options: A. To look for moments that were exciting or thrilling, B. To look for moments that were mundane or ordinary, C. To look for moments that were significant or memorable, D. To look for moments that were happy or sad Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the author's main argument about the importance of slow motion in writing? Options: A. Slow motion is a necessary element in all narratives, B. Slow motion is an important element in some narratives, but not all, C. Slow motion is not an important element in any narratives, D. Slow motion is only used in fiction narratives Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the author's final message to the reader about the role of the writer in controlling the narrative? Options: A. The writer has complete control over the narrative, B. The writer has some control over the narrative, but not complete control, C. The writer has no control over the narrative, D. The writer's control over the narrative is limited to the words they choose Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions refer to the phenomenon described by the author as happening when they recall a car accident from their past, and both questions have options that relate to the author's memory of the accident. The correct option for both questions is also similar, with the ground truth MCQ stating "Our memories slow down time when exciting things happen" and the generated MCQ stating "The accident took longer than it actually did". 

While the wording is not identical, the meaning and intent behind the questions are the same, making Question 1 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I got in my first car accident when I was sixteen. I had just gotten my license and I was driving home when a car pulled into the intersection and bang! It hit me. The ball nudged the back rim, falling through the net with a gentle, satisfying swish. And the crowd exploded from their seats." See, we just slowed down time through our writing. The bottom line is this: there are moments in life that take longer than they actually take. When you're planning out your narrative, think about those moments, those snippets of life that took longer than the watch: the moment of hearing bad news, the moment of hearing good news, the moment of exhilaration when you realize you hit the jump, or the moment when you realize you aren't going to land it. Once you identify these moments in your narrative, you can use this effect of slow motion when you write. Just remember, it's not enough to say, "time slowed down" and it's not enough to throw a couple adjectives in a sentence and call it done either. Descriptive writing is good writing, that's true. But if you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually take up more physical space on the page, use more film so to speak. In doing so, you will create tension and keep your reader interested. And that way, the next time you write, you'll control the camera of your own writing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What parallel does Sitze make about slowing down time in writing?
Options: A. Kelvin chambers slow molecular movement to a halt, and that will inform the way to slow time in writing, B. The way ornithologists see birds wings in time lapse footage is an example of a way to do it in writing, C. The way filmmakers slow down time will inform the way to do it in writing, D. By speeding up time, you can slow it down -- it's similar to reverse psychology
Correct Option: C

The author's memory of the accident is the same as the actual event Correct Option: A

The need to slow down time in writing to capture important moments, C. The role of the author's perspective in shaping the narrative, D. To create a sense of tension, C. To create a sense of slow motion, D. To create a sense of relief Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the key to creating slow motion in writing, according to the author? Options: A. Using more adjectives, B. Using more descriptive language, C. Taking up more physical space on the page, D. Using a faster pace Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I got in my first car accident when I was sixteen. I had just gotten my license and I was driving home when a car pulled into the intersection and bang! It hit me. It had happened that quick. Bang! But when I play that memory back, it doesn't take two seconds. I see the tires of the car rolling through the stop sign, I have time to think, "You know, I think that car is going to hit me." I see the right-hand corner of the hood crumple up like tin foil, I see the red paint flake off and drift off into the air, I can see all of that, like it's happening in slow motion. In my memory, that experience takes ten seconds. But why? Why did that memory play back longer than the actual time it took? This is an interesting phenomenon and it's not just for car accidents, a roller coaster, or a first kiss. These events seem to take longer than they actually take. But why? And when it comes to writing about that experience, how do I get that peculiar feeling across? How do I slow down time as a writer? To get the answer, we have to visit Hollywood. You see, the way filmmakers create slow motion will tell us a lot about how writers can create slow motion. First, let's remember how film works. When the camera turns on, it's not recording motion, it's taking lots and lots of individual pictures. Then when those pictures are played back in the projector, they blend together and create the appearance of motion, like a flip book. So, let's imagine that a camera man needs to film his actress skipping through a field of daisies in regular motion. Ready, action. She skips across the field, he records it, and...cut. Let's say for the sake of easy math that our camera man took 50 pictures, 50 little frames on that length of film. Now, let's take that film and play it back at the rate of 50 frames per 5 seconds. This rate is constant, the projector will always go at the same speed. It's easy, we got 50 frames, so our film takes 5 seconds. She skips across the field... ...and cut! So, then, how do we slow down time in film? How do we create slow motion? Maybe this is a surprise, but we don't take less pictures, we take more pictures. Ready, action! She skips across the field, he records it, and cut. Now we have a lot of film, a long length, let's say 100 frames long. Now, when we play it back, it takes a longer time to get through, and there's the actress in slow motion. Skipping through the field of daisies! Which brings us now to writing. When you're writing a narrative, you may want to use slow motion in one of your scenes. It's a cool effect, just like it is in Hollywood, and it draws the reader's attention to important moments. Well, here's how you do it. You see, when we read, our brain makes the words into pictures and the pictures blend into action. So what we read is what we see in the time it takes us to read it. For example, imagine you're writing a narrative about your game-winning free throw in the championship game. Here's a moment as a writer that you might want to slow down time to really capture the second-by-second tension produced by the scene. You concentrate, you put the pencil to paper, you really want to slow down time, you write, "I shot the ball in the hoop. Time slowed down. Then we won." To read that, takes two seconds; therefore, your reader imagines a scene that takes two seconds. Ball goes up, comes down, done. See, even though you wrote, "time slowed down," you didn't achieve that effect for your reader. Just saying it doesn't make it happen. Now, let's take what we make about film, time slows down with more pictures, and try again. This time write A LOT more. "I bent my knees and held the ball loosely. Letting the ball bounce on the floor once more, I gathered my thoughts. This was the moment. My right arm extended as I released the ball with a gentle flick, it rotated slightly as it arched toward the rim. I held my breath. The ball nudged the back rim, falling through the net with a gentle, satisfying swish. And the crowd exploded from their seats." See, we just slowed down time through our writing. The bottom line is this: there are moments in life that take longer than they actually take. When you're planning out your narrative, think about those moments, those snippets of life that took longer than the watch: the moment of hearing bad news, the moment of hearing good news, the moment of exhilaration when you realize you hit the jump, or the moment when you realize you aren't going to land it. Once you identify these moments in your narrative, you can use this effect of slow motion when you write. Just remember, it's not enough to say, "time slowed down" and it's not enough to throw a couple adjectives in a sentence and call it done either. Descriptive writing is good writing, that's true. But if you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually take up more physical space on the page, use more film so to speak. In doing so, you will create tension and keep your reader interested. And that way, the next time you write, you'll control the camera of your own writing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we make slow motion in film?
Options: A. We take less pictures per amount of time, B. We take more pictures per amount of time, C. We take the same amount of pictures, and just play it slowly, D. All of the above
Correct Option: B

This is an interesting phenomenon and it's not just for car accidents, a roller coaster, or a first kiss. These events seem to take longer than they actually take. But why? And when it comes to writing about that experience, how do I get that peculiar feeling across? How do I slow down time as a writer? To get the answer, we have to visit Hollywood. You see, the way filmmakers create slow motion will tell us a lot about how writers can create slow motion. First, let's remember how film works. When the camera turns on, it's not recording motion, it's taking lots and lots of individual pictures. Then when those pictures are played back in the projector, they blend together and create the appearance of motion, like a flip book. So, let's imagine that a camera man needs to film his actress skipping through a field of daisies in regular motion. Ready, action. She skips across the field, he records it, and...cut. Let's say for the sake of easy math that our camera man took 50 pictures, 50 little frames on that length of film. Now, let's take that film and play it back at the rate of 50 frames per 5 seconds. So, then, how do we slow down time in film? How do we create slow motion? Maybe this is a surprise, but we don't take less pictures, we take more pictures. Ready, action! She skips across the field, he records it, and cut. Now we have a lot of film, a long length, let's say 100 frames long. Now, when we play it back, it takes a longer time to get through, and there's the actress in slow motion. Skipping through the field of daisies! Which brings us now to writing. When you're writing a narrative, you may want to use slow motion in one of your scenes. It's a cool effect, just like it is in Hollywood, and it draws the reader's attention to important moments. Well, here's how you do it. You see, when we read, our brain makes the words into pictures and the pictures blend into action. So what we read is what we see in the time it takes us to read it. For example, imagine you're writing a narrative about your game-winning free throw in the championship game. You concentrate, you put the pencil to paper, you really want to slow down time, you write, "I shot the ball in the hoop. Time slowed down. Then we won." To read that, takes two seconds; therefore, your reader imagines a scene that takes two seconds. Ball goes up, comes down, done. Letting the ball bounce on the floor once more, I gathered my thoughts. This was the moment. My right arm extended as I released the ball with a gentle flick, it rotated slightly as it arched toward the rim. I held my breath. The ball nudged the back rim, falling through the net with a gentle, satisfying swish. And the crowd exploded from their seats." See, we just slowed down time through our writing. The bottom line is this: there are moments in life that take longer than they actually take. Just remember, it's not enough to say, "time slowed down" and it's not enough to throw a couple adjectives in a sentence and call it done either. Descriptive writing is good writing, that's true. But if you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually take up more physical space on the page, use more film so to speak. In doing so, you will create tension and keep your reader interested. And that way, the next time you write, you'll control the camera of your own writing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is true about slowing down time in writing?
Options: A. When we read, our brains make the words into pictures, and the pictures blend into action, B. To effectively slow down time, we should capture each detail about an event (especially any tension that may exist), C. Using phrases like "time slowed down" always encourages the reader to imagine an event, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar I got in my first car accident when I was sixteen. I had just gotten my license and I was driving home when a car pulled into the intersection and bang! It hit me. It had happened that quick. Bang! But when I play that memory back, it doesn't take two seconds. I see the tires of the car rolling through the stop sign, I have time to think, "You know, I think that car is going to hit me." I see the right-hand corner of the hood crumple up like tin foil, I see the red paint flake off and drift off into the air, I can see all of that, like it's happening in slow motion. In my memory, that experience takes ten seconds. But why? Why did that memory play back longer than the actual time it took? This is an interesting phenomenon and it's not just for car accidents, a roller coaster, or a first kiss. These events seem to take longer than they actually take. But why? And when it comes to writing about that experience, how do I get that peculiar feeling across? How do I slow down time as a writer? To get the answer, we have to visit Hollywood. You see, the way filmmakers create slow motion will tell us a lot about how writers can create slow motion. First, let's remember how film works. When the camera turns on, it's not recording motion, it's taking lots and lots of individual pictures. Then when those pictures are played back in the projector, they blend together and create the appearance of motion, like a flip book. So, let's imagine that a camera man needs to film his actress skipping through a field of daisies in regular motion. Ready, action. She skips across the field, he records it, and...cut. When you're writing a narrative, you may want to use slow motion in one of your scenes. It's a cool effect, just like it is in Hollywood, and it draws the reader's attention to important moments. Well, here's how you do it. You see, when we read, our brain makes the words into pictures and the pictures blend into action. So what we read is what we see in the time it takes us to read it. The bottom line is this: there are moments in life that take longer than they actually take. But if you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually take up more physical space on the page, use more film so to speak. In doing so, you will create tension and keep your reader interested. And that way, the next time you write, you'll control the camera of your own writing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sitze says, "If you want to express the feeling of slow motion in life, you have to actually ____________."
Options: A. Take up more physical space on the page, B. Explain every minute detail about the characters and the setting, C. Film an event first and then record in writing what you see, verbatim, D. Set up the slow motion to your reader by telling him/her that you are slowing down time
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What is the phenomenon described by the author as happening when they recall a car accident from their past? Options: A. The accident took longer than it actually did, B. The use of adjectives to create a vivid picture Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the author, how does a filmmaker create slow motion in film? Options: A. By taking fewer pictures, B. By taking more pictures, C. By using a faster film speed, D. By using a slower film speed Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the effect that the author wants to achieve when writing a narrative about a moment that took longer than it actually did? Options: A. To create a sense of urgency, B. To create a sense of tension, C. To create a sense of slow motion, D. To create a sense of relief Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the key to creating slow motion in writing, according to the author? Options: A. Using more adjectives, B. Using more descriptive language, C. Taking up more physical space on the page, D. Using a faster pace Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the author's advice to the reader about how to write a narrative that captures the feeling of slow motion? Options: A. To say "time slowed down" and add a few adjectives, B. To write a lot more and use descriptive language, C. To use a faster pace and more adjectives, D. To use a slower pace and fewer adjectives Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main idea that the author wants to convey to the reader about the role of the author's perspective in shaping the narrative? Options: A. The author's perspective is the only way to tell a story, B. The author's perspective is important, but not the only way to tell a story, C. The author's perspective is not important in shaping the narrative, D. The author's perspective is not relevant to the narrative Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the author's advice to the reader about how to identify moments in life that took longer than they actually did? Options: A. To look for moments that were exciting or thrilling, B. To look for moments that were mundane or ordinary, C. To look for moments that were significant or memorable, D. To look for moments that were happy or sad Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the author's main argument about the importance of slow motion in writing? Options: A. Slow motion is a necessary element in all narratives, B. Slow motion is an important element in some narratives, but not all, C. Slow motion is not an important element in any narratives, D. Slow motion is only used in fiction narratives Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the author's final message to the reader about the role of the writer in controlling the narrative? Options: A. The writer has complete control over the narrative, B. The writer has some control over the narrative, but not complete control, C. The writer has no control over the narrative, D. The writer's control over the narrative is limited to the words they choose Correct Option: B
